I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In September 2001, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved its Social Protection 
Strategy covering five areas identified by ADB as main target areas of social protection: (i) labor 
markets, (ii) social insurance, (iii) social assistance, (iv) micro-insurance schemes, and (v) child 
protection. The Government of Pakistan’s Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) gives high 
priority to improving social protection. ADB is assisting the Government in various areas of 
social protection, including early childhood development,  health,  and  education. Under the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, ADB is also supporting a pilot project to improve the health 
and nutrition status of marginalized women and children.1 
 
2.  ADB’s Country Strategy Program (CSP) for Pakistan (2002-2004), includes a social 
protection  study  in  2003  for  $350,000  to  identify  the  scope  and  strategies  for  (i)  social 
protection, and (ii) specifically for health insurance.2 For 2006, the CSP (2004-2006) foresees a 
loan project on social health insurance. 
 
3.  ADB conducted a Fact-finding Mission from 9–23 May 2003. The Mission reached an 
understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  objectives,  scope,  financing,  implementation 
arrangements, and terms of reference of the study. The technical assistance (TA) framework is 
shown in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  With a population of 143 million growing at a rate of 2.4% per year, Pakistan is ranked 
138  of  173  countries  covered  by  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  Human 
Development  Index.  It  falls  under  the  category  "low  human  development." It is generally 
accepted that the declining trend in poverty during the 1970s and 1980s was reversed in the 
1990s. The incidence of poverty increased from 26.6% in 1993 to 32.1% in 2000, during which 
period the number of poor increased by over 12 million. Since 1999, economic growth has 
slowed  further,  development  spending  has  continued  to  decline,  and  the  country  has 
experienced a severe drought. It is therefore highly likely that the incidence of poverty today is 
significantly higher than in 1999.3 
 
5.  Poverty rose more sharply in the rural areas in the 1990s, and in 1999 the incidence of 
rural poverty (36.3%) was significantly higher than that of urban poverty (22.6%). Inequality also 
increased in all four provinces. In 1997, the income share of the bottom 20% of households had 
declined to 6.9%, from 7.9% in 1987, and the income share of the bottom 40% of households 
had declined from 20% to 18%. 
 
6.  Apart from poverty, vulnerability is of importance when discussing the issues related to 
social protection. Vulnerability is the risk of falling below the poverty line. In Pakistan, in addition 
to those mentioned above, who live below the poverty line, large numbers of people, due to their 
vulnerability, face the risk of becoming poor or face transitory poverty. 
 
7.  Even though there is a large need, social protection is very limited in Pakistan. This 
counts for all the five areas of social protection identified by the ADB Social Protection Strategy. 
There is no general or universal social protection in Pakistan. However, a number of initiatives 
aimed at helping the poor (by improving governance and functioning public sector institutions;

creating assets, employment, and income generation opportunities; revamping social safety net 
systems; and improving access to basic services) are being implemented. The schemes are run  
by the Government, and also by nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and the private sector. 
 
8.  At present, the formal social security systems are restricted to groups like civil servants, 
army, police, as well as some formal sector enterprises (with five or more employees). Formal 
sector social security provisions include (i) the provincially based Employees' Social Security 
System, (ii) the Employees' Old Age Benefits Institution, and (iii) the Workers Welfare Fund. 
None of these schemes covers workers from the agriculture sector, the informal economy, or 
those in formal sector who are temporarily employed or employed in establishments with fewer 
than five employees. The coverage of these schemes is less than 3% of the total employed 
labor  force.  There  are  hardly  any  informal,  traditional,  community-based  insurance 
arrangements (for example micro-insurance). There is also a gender and rural-urban bias in 
existing social protection schemes. 
 
9.  The Government has, over the years, undertaken several public works programs to 
create assets and employment opportunities for the poor. The most recent, the Khushhal 
Pakistan Program, is an integrated small public works program. There are other social welfare 
arrangements for certain groups. Among the existing social safety nets are the Zakat Fund, the 
Baut-ul-Maal, as well as the Food Support Program and many NGOs, which are giving support 
to the poor. But still most people lack protection from all major life risks, including ill health, 
death, disability, old age, unemployment, and natural disasters. 
 
10.  Some ongoing projects and activities, financed mainly by international donors, have a 
link to social protection. In the field of health insurance, the World Bank is funding a small pilot 
project  in  North-West  Frontier  Province.  The  United  States  Agency  for  International 
Development has funded a report on Policy Options for Financing Health Services in Pakistan, 
and the International Labour Organization is implementing a series of TAs. One planned project 
that will have significant relevance for the present study is Social Protection in Pakistan for 
Poverty Reduction under the Decent Work Program, which will review policy recommendations 
for social protection, especially reform of pension schemes and occupational health and safety 
systems.  
 
11.   However, the existing social protection schemes and activities remain scattered, and 
coverage is low. While these activities bring benefits to certain population groups, they rarely 
contribute to strategic change unless they are linked to policy development. There is also a 
need to strengthen the existing services from public and private sources. Capacity building will 
help to make sure that there are no leakages and that funds entirely reach the poor. Hence, this 
would be very important as a basis for the development of a social protection strategy for the 
country.  
 
12.  Major health incidents, especially those of catastrophic dimensions, may aggravate the 
poverty of private households or may even lead to bankruptcy of families. "The development of 
the private health sector is also constrained by the low level of development of the health 
insurance industry. The lack of access to health insurance poses a major problem for the 
financing of care for catastrophic episodes of illness and injuries."4 Risk pooling, for example 
through health insurance, may prevent households from falling into poverty, and those who are 
already poor will have the chance to get access to better health services. Health insurance thus 
makes a major contribution to poverty reduction and prevention. Even in cases where health 
insurance does not pay for services, it can provide a service to customers through negotiation of 
                                                 
4 WB. 1998. Concept Paper on a Microinsurance Pilot Project in NWFP. Washington,D.C.

3 
prices for health care and thus make the costs of services more transparent. At several levels, 
health insurance became an issue in Pakistan. The Federal Ministry of Health is discussing 
alternatives on how to extend coverage of health insurance. The Government of Punjab has 
installed a task force to look into the feasibility of health insurance for a broader population. 
Interest in the subject is thus increasing. 
 
13.  The affordability and sustainability of social protection in a country where economic 
indicators are weak has to be examined. Economic growth may be one source that can support 
social protection. The performance of several sectors of the economy has been improving this 
year. But often such growth benefits only part of the population and does not lead to a 
proportional increase of welfare. Therefore, growth has to be pro-poor and socially inclusive, 
meaning that it should contribute to poverty reduction. Social protection can be one element 
contributing to this if the poor have mechanisms that protect them from shocks and increase 
their ability to take risks (for example business activities) to pursue livelihood. Social protection 
interventions can have positive effects on the demand and the willingness of the people to take 
risks, and contribute to building social cohesion and social stability in the country. The right 
moment to start a discussion is when the problems emerge in order to be prepared for and to 
prepare pro-poor growth. Therefore it is necessary to identify appropriate sources of funding for 
social protection measures. First, funding can be effected by changing the budget allocation. 
For this purpose, there is a need to show the Government what can be done with social 
protection, what the benefits are, and what it costs. Second, existing programs can be analyzed 
in order to optimize the use of scarce funds. Third, the source can be foreign assistance. 
However, this has a risk of not being sustainable, especially for the poorest sections of the 
society. Therefore a long-term strategy is needed showing where funds might be needed. 
Fourth, the source can be individual  contributions  (risk  pooling).  Insurance schemes have 
shown that they can protect people from economic risks like sickness, old age poverty, and 
natural disasters. An extension of existing social insurance schemes may be an option. The TA 
will examine all of these possible sources of funds to support social protection. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
14.  The purpose of the study is to assist the Government in elaborating ways of reducing 
vulnerability, particularly among the poorest sections of the society, and to contribute towards 
translating the Government’s policy objective of poverty reduction into effective social protection 
programs. The TA is in line with the PRSP and with ADB's Social Protection Strategy.  
 
15.  The output will be a proposal to the Government for a comprehensive and coordinated 
plan for social protection development as well as a feasibility study for health insurance. The 
plan for social protection development will include (i) a definition of social protection in Pakistan; 
(ii) priority areas of intervention including a ranking of priorities – with a special focus on self-
sustaining social protection mechanisms; (iii) target groups; (iv) identification of needs for 
institutional development; (v) costs of proposed interventions and financing options; and (vi) 
possible involvement of the Government, development partners, and ADB. The feasibility study 
on health insurance will, as a result, provide recommendations for further activities. An outline of 
the whole study can be found in Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
16.  The  TA  will  have  2  components:  Component  1  will  be  the  comprehensive  social 
protection strategy covering all elements of social protection mentioned in the ADB Social

4 
 
Protection  Strategy.  Component  2  will  be  a  feasibility  study  on  health  insurance,  as  one 
important part of social protection.  
 
17.  Component 1 will provide a comprehensive analysis of the sector including the following 
activities: (i) elaboration of an inventory of existing social protection arrangements (formal and 
nonformal), including description of arrangements, target group, coverage, financial dimensions, 
and  evaluation;  (ii)  assessment  and  evaluation  activities  by  NGOs  and  international  aid 
agencies; (iii) a needs assessment with the view to provide social protection; (iv) identification of 
quantitative  dimensions  of  social  protection;  (v)  identification  of  target  groups  for  social 
protection activities, taking into account indigenous/ethnic minorities; (vi) identification of social 
protection  measures  that  are  capable  of  reducing  poverty  and  helping  the  target  groups; 
(vii) identification  of  costs  and  financing  possibilities  for  these  measures;  and 
(viii) recommendations for further strategic interventions (plan of social protection development).  
 
18.  Component 2: As a concrete application of the Social Protection Study, it is proposed to 
evaluate the possibility of a health insurance in Pakistan for population groups that are not 
covered by existing arrangements and that have problems accessing adequate health care due 
to high costs of treatment. The activities of this component are (i) a situation analysis (health 
expenditure, needs, and ability to pay of the poor households); (ii) defining target groups of a 
possible health insurance scheme; (iii) identification of implementation arrangements; (iv) needs 
for awareness building among stakeholders; (v) evaluation of possible administrative setup; 
(vi) assessment of marketing needs and possibilities of the product, especially among the poor; 
(vii) assessment of possibilities of public-private partnerships; (viii) possible arrangements with 
providers;  (ix)  administrative  arrangements;  (x)  product  design  and  benefits  of  a  health 
insurance; (xi) estimates of costs of a possible health insurance plan; (xii) possible financing of 
health insurance; (xiii) possibilities of cooperation with and lessons learned from other projects 
in the field of health insurance; (xiv) recommendations for further actions; and (xv) lessons 
learned from other countries. The component will be targeting the poor. The study is required 
because health insurance is new in Pakistan. There is little expertise about how to set up this 
kind of health insurance. If it should be possible to establish health insurance in Pakistan, 
public-private partnerships might play an important role (for example with private insurance 
companies, especially in the fields of capacity building, risk sharing, and awareness building). 
Another option is the involvement of the Zakat Fund, Fitrana, and other institutions in order to 
help to establish health insurance in Pakistan. All these options will be looked into during the 
feasibility study. 
 
19.  Given the differences among the provinces in Pakistan, the geographical scope of the 
TA will be all four provinces. The TA will be closely coordinated with the ministries and 
stakeholders involved and other development partners. It will put special focus on possible 
public-private  partnerships  and  involvement  of  NGOs.  Contacts  with  NGOs  and  private 
insurance (EFU ALLIANZ) during reconnaissance and fact-finding showed a broad interest to 
support the TA. It will build on a series of studies and projects carried out by national and 
international organizations in terms of lessons learned. But given the limited size of other 
activities, ADB will make a significant contribution to develop social protection and especially 
health insurance in the country. At least two workshops will be held with government agencies 
involved in social protection, development partners, NGOs, and academics. The study will be 
closely coordinated with the planned ILO study on social protection in order to achieve synergy 
and avoid duplication. In the field of health insurance, experiences from the World Bank project 
will be  taken into account. The final study will be published and shared with government 
agencies and interested aid agencies and stakeholders for future policy and project formulation.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
20.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $437,500 equivalent, of which $263,000 will be 
foreign currency cost, and $174,500 equivalent will be local currency cost. ADB will finance 
$350,000 equivalent, which will include the entire foreign currency cost and $87,000 equivalent 
in  local  currency  costs.  The  remaining  $87,500  equivalent  will  be  contributed  by  the 
Government and will include office accommodation, counterpart staff remuneration, surveys, 
and workshops. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from ADB's TA funding program. The 
detailed cost estimates and financing plan are shown in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be the Ministry of Labor (MoL), led by the Joint 
Secretary. A steering committee, headed by the Joint Secretary, MoL will be created. Members 
of  the  steering  committee  will  be  representatives  from  the  Ministry  of  Finance;  Planning 
Commission; Ministry of Health; Ministry of Women Development, Social Welfare and Special 
Education;  as  well  as  provincial,  private  sector,  and  NGO  representatives.  The  steering 
committee will meet at least three times. The consulting team and the steering committee will be 
assisted by a technical working group (TWG). The main task of the TWG (see Appendix 4) is to 
serve as a critical partner in reviewing the outputs, give advice on optimizing the results, and 
support the project in specific areas. 
 
22.  The TA will be carried out over 5 months, beginning in November 2003 and ending in 
March 2004. There will be a total input of 22 person-months (pm) of consultancy: 10 pm of 
international and 12 pm of domestic services. The consulting team will include as international 
consultants a social protection specialist/team leader (5 pm) and a health insurance specialist  
(5 pm); and as domestic consultants an economist specializing in social protection (3 pm), a 
legal specialist specializing in social and labor law (3 pm), a community development and 
gender specialist (3 pm), and a poverty analyst (3 pm).  
 
23.  All consultants will be recruited through a firm using simplified technical proposals, in 
accordance with ADB’s guidelines for the recruitment of consultants. Quality and Cost-Based 
Selection will be used for consultant selection. A project director from MoL will be in charge of 
coordinating the other government agencies. 
 
24.  The consultants will submit three reports: An inception report will be submitted no later 
than 2 weeks after fielding of the consultants. A draft final report will be submitted 4 months 
after inception. Both the Government and ADB will provide comments on the draft final report. 
The final report will be submitted within 1 month after receiving comments from the review. The 
outline terms of reference are in Appendix 4. 
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for preparing the Social Protection Strategy Development Study, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
1.  The consulting team for the technical assistance (TA) will comprise two international 
consultants  and  four  domestic  consultants,  recruited  under  a  firm  through  the  Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB) simplified procedure, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic 
consultants. Each consultant is required to work with the team and the technical working group 
(TWG) in developing all outputs (see section C for the terms of reference of the TWG). The 
consultants will take into account the relevant ADB handbooks, especially the one on poverty 
and  social  analysis,  the  Social  Protection  Strategy,  and  ADB's  Policy  on  Gender  and 
Development. The specific technical tasks associated with each consultant are outlined below. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Social Protection Specialist/Team Leader (5 person-months) 
 
2.  The specialist should have a solid background and experience in the field of formal and 
informal sector social protection instruments including health care. He/she should have broad 
experience in developing countries. 
 
3.  The specialist will also ensure that gender issues are adequately mainstreamed by 
identifying gender biases in existing social protection arrangements and proposing measures to 
improve the situation of women with view to social protection.  
 
4.  As team leader, he/she will be responsible for the following activities:  
 
(i)  preparation of the TA inception report including a detailed work plan for the team; 
(ii)  consolidation of TA outputs before and after each scheduled mission;  
(iii)  regular consultation with  the Government’s steering committee, the Executing 
Agency,  other  development  partners,  and  ADB  on  the  issues  and 
recommendations of the study;  
(iv)  preparation of the draft final report with required revisions for finalization based 
on a tripartite review; and  
(v)  coordination of the activities of the other team members. 
 
5.  The activities as social protection specialist include, but are not limited to the following:  
 
(i)  review and assess in detail all existing programs and arrangements for social 
protection by various government and nongovernment actors; 
(ii)  agree on a definition of what constitutes social protection in Pakistan; 
(iii)  define, in cooperation with the poverty analyst, the priority target groups, their 
exposure to risks, and their need for social protection arrangements; 
(iv)  conduct several participatory workshops and focus group discussions to assess 
needs, formulate priorities, and introduce the process of social protection, with 
assistance of the poverty analyst and the community development and gender 
specialist; 
(v)  adapt lessons learned from other projects and studies; 
(vi)  together  with  the  health  insurance  specialist,  propose  activities  and 
arrangements for social protection; identify possible ADB and other development 
partners' contributions to these arrangements in close consultation with them;

(vii)  propose possible activities in the field of capacity building of officials on their role 
and relevant issues to enable them to perform as a catalyst to address the needs 
of the target group; 
(viii)  work closely with the International Labour Organization (ILO) team preparing the 
ILO Social Protection Study; 
(ix)  prepare a workshop with government representatives and development partners 
involved in proposals and studies in order to discuss the team's proposals; and 
(x)  produce and consolidate a report (see outline in Appendix 2) for discussion with 
the Executing Agency and the TWG including recommendations for improving 
and establishing new social protection arrangements. 
 
2.  Health Insurance Specialist  (5 person-months) 
 
6.  The specialist will work with the social protection specialist and help the Government to 
develop a vision and strategy supporting social health insurance development. The activities will 
include the following: 
 
(i)  assess  existing  proposals  and  studies  made  on  this  issue  in  Pakistan  by 
development partners and others; 
(ii)  assess the technical feasibility of health insurance in Pakistan, especially  
(a)  evaluate and draw on existing schemes, plans and initiatives in the field 
of health insurance;  
(b)  define target groups of a possible health insurance; 
(c)  evaluate possible arrangements with providers; 
(d)  outline administrative arrangements; 
(e)  identify benefits of health insurance; 
(f)  estimate costs of a possible health insurance scheme; and 
(g)  define possible financing arrangements of health insurance; 
(iii)  assess the possible cooperation with various stakeholders, especially with the 
private  and  nongovernment  organization  sectors,  and  suggest  ways  for  its 
strengthening; and 
(iv)  develop a report with proposals for extension of health insurance coverage 
according  the  outline  in  Appendix  2,  including  a  detailed  strategy  for  the 
implementation  of  the  proposed  interventions;  undertake  risk  analysis;  and 
identify possibilities for ADB programming.  
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
 
1.  Economist specializing in Social Protection (3 person-months) 
 
7.  The  economist  will  prepare  a  comprehensive  analysis  that  supports  the  economic 
impacts and justification of the strategy proposed by the study and demonstrates the cost-
effectiveness of the proposed interventions.  
 
8.  Moreover, the economist will 
 
(i)  coordinate the collation of data on government expenditures on social protection 
(amount, sources, and funding channels) and assess the implications of future 
financing  arrangements  (including  copayments  or  user  fees  on  access  to 
services by the poorest), drawing on studies performed in this area;

(iii)  provide,  in  cooperation  with  the  social  protection  specialist  and  the  health

development, and investment needs; and 
(iv)  contribute to the final report. 
 
2.  Legal Specialist specializing in Social and Labor Law (3 person-months) 
 
9.  The legal specialist will  
 
(i)  review all acts and regulations pertaining to social protection;  
(ii)  review  the  results  of  existing  studies  and  consolidate  the  information  with 
relevance to the study, identifying gaps and areas of special concern; 
(iii)  identify key issues in the legal reform process that need to be addressed in order 
to implement the proposed social protection strategy; 
(iv)  identify regulations and structures that promote and obstruct gender equity and 
make recommendations, 
(v)  coordinate with local bodies and working groups to incorporate relevant legal 
issues and crosscutting issues in the proposed social protection strategy; and 
(vi)  make contributions to the final report related to his/her field. 
 
3.  Community Development and Gender Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
10.  The community development specialist will  
 
(i)  review the situation of the target groups at the community level by gender, and 
identify necessary ways of expressing their needs and complaints; 
(ii)  together with the poverty analyst, conduct participatory workshops and  focus 
group discussions with mixed and women-only groups at various levels (national, 
district,  community)  to  assess  needs,  formulate  priorities,  and  introduce  the 
process of social protection; 
(iii)  prepare a stakeholder analysis and assessment report along with a proposed 
participation strategy for implementation of social protection measures; 
(iv)  identify and formulate, together with the relevant ministries and government and 
non-government institutions, a strategy for community level support to the most 
disadvantaged groups; 
(v)  identify possible pilot projects at local levels, including social protection service 
delivery to disadvantaged groups, and strengthening local bodies and agencies 
through training and capacity building on social protection issues to be tested; 
and 
(vi)  make contributions to the final report related to his/her field. 
 
4.  Poverty Analyst (3 person-months) 
 
11.  The poverty analyst will work closely with the team leader and the Executing Agency to 
identify the target groups, municipalities, and districts most in need of social protection. The 
specialist will then

Appendix 4  13 
(i)  prepare a summary risk and vulnerability profile according to ADB methodology, 
drawing on studies prepared by other development partners in this area;  
(ii)  identify the potential beneficiaries of the proposed social protection measures, 
and the likely impact on the availability/access of essential services;  
(iii)  work with the social protection specialist on demand issues for services, and 
address  participation  and  demand  more  generally  for  the  targeted  groups; 
conduct focus group discussions with target  groups in order to find out their 
needs and preferences;  
(iv)  quantify  the  poverty  impact  of  proposed  interventions  either  directly  (e.g., 
numbers of beneficiaries receiving essential social protection services, by men 
and women) or indirectly (availability of services, including referral systems, to 
targeted beneficiaries);  
(v)  identify  risks  of  failure  to  achieve  the  objectives,  and  steps  to  be  taken  to 
minimize those risks;  
(vi)  examine the likelihood of benefit leakages to the nonpoor and steps to correct 
this;    identify  the  credible  instruments  for  targeting  and  monitoring  poverty 
impacts;  
(vii)  work with the social protection specialist to identify performance indicators and 
methodologies,  and  human  resources  required  to  support  the  proposed 
measures,  baseline  and  later  evaluation  surveys,  and  project  monitoring  of 
poverty impact on the target groups; and  
(viii)  contribute to the final report related to his/her field. 
 
C.  Technical Working Group  
 
12.  The consulting team will be working closely together with the TWG. The main task of the 
TWG is to serve as a critical partner in reviewing the outputs, giving advice on optimizing the 
results, and supporting the study team in specific areas, namely examining the options to 
support a strategic plan for social protection in Pakistan, discussing the funding mechanisms, 
helping to identify the core topics and policy issues that should be preferentially supported, 
identifying and evaluating ongoing and past studies and projects and their programmatic impact 
for replication. 
 
13.  The members of the TWG will be appointed in close consultation between the team 
leader and the Executing Agency. The TWG will meet at least three times during the study 
period  of  5  months.  Members  will  include  representatives  from  employers,  trade  unions, 
academia, the private sector, nongovernment organizations, international organizations, and 
district and provincial bodies.
